data.text: Contents
Introduction

Waste Disposal is the generic term given to the whole spectrum of activities associated with waste, namely generation, handling, storage and actual disposal, which continues right up until the final destruction of that waste. The Trust has a “cradle to grave” responsibility and must ensure that the Trust's arrangements recognise this responsibility.

Hospitals by their very nature generate a significant amount of every conceivable classification and category of waste, each of which has their own disposal standards and routes. This makes for a very complicated system of controls, which need to be easily understood and implemented at shop floor level. Therefore particular effort has been made to simplify the guidance issued, which primarily involves the Policy itself, which is then supplemented by a code of practice and waste disposal data sheets (WDDS).
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Set out the measures required by the Trust to ensure compliance with regard to waste management
To provide clear guidelines on the safe handling, segregation or separation, minimisation, storage, transportation, recycling and disposal of all waste generated by the Trust

Apply measures to all members of staff who work for or on behalf of the Trust and includes legal requirements and healthcare standards known at the time of either the release of the policy or as and when it is amended due to any known legal changes

Assign personnel with responsibility for ensuring that waste management procedures are followed and provide clear and unambiguous procedures for the management of wastes arising the Trust's activities
This policy applies to all services directly provided by the Trust and all staff should familiarise themselves with the policy.
This policy encompasses the activities and responsibilities of all Trust staff, including in patients' homes, Dental Surgeries and Community clinics when applicable.
This policy applies also to all contractors and temporary workers who are engaged to work on the Trust premises.
Definitions

table_items.text: Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations 2002 as amended.
Department of Health and Social Care
The clinical and hazardous waste regulator for England and Wales
Hazardous Waste Consignment Note A mandatory document which must accompany all hazardous wastes as it moves from point of generation to point of final disposal.
Medicinal products as defined under The Medicines Act 1968 and all related regulations.
Use components, chemical or otherwise to make something else, e.g. shredded waste paper to make toilet rolls
Use again in its present form by someone else, e.g. second hand goods
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Health and Safety Groups will monitor the effectiveness of this policy by reviewing the delivery of the implementation plan and through its on-going review of incident data.

Waste Management Groups shall approve this Policy and associated Procedures. The Group shall receive performance reports in respect of waste management and require actions to implement the Policy as required.
Infection Prevention Committee to ensure that all waste activities fall within the guidelines for infection control along with any changes to legislation, HTM guidelines, etc.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group (MAG)
Approval of all processes related to disposal of pharmaceuticals
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse or site Director of Nursing and Chief Medical Officer or site Medical Directors as appropriate related to medicines disposal;
Exception reporting to Health & Safety Group and/or Risk and Compliance Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning the disposal of pharmaeuticals, including controlled drugs.

Board of Directors has a duty placed on it by a variety of health and safety legislation, which includes the Hazardous Waste Regulations, the Controlled Waste Regulations and the Health and Safety at Work Act to ensure the safe segregation, collection and disposal of healthcare waste from all areas of the Trust. This ensures that as far as reasonably practicable patients, staff and visitors are not put at risk by the activities of the Trust.

Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust and up to data procedural documents in place to govern and guide activities. The implementation of this duty is delegated to the Executive Directors whom oversee specific portfolios of activity.

Director of Operations has executive responsibility for health & safety matters across MSE and will be responsible to the Chief Executive for the Trusts day to day compliance with the requirements of this policy.

Portering & Waste Manager has responsibility to prepare the Policy for Trust approval and organise safe system of work that will ensure the safe segregation, handling, collection, storage and control of waste throughout the Trust and to put in place arrangements for the effective disposal of waste.

The Portering & Waste Manager will provide Procedures which are to be applied across the Trust and or local procedures as required to ensure that appropriate instructions available across all areas of the Trust to extract this Policy.

Departmental Managers, Line Managers and Supervisory Staff It will be a line management responsibility to ensure the implementation and adherence to the Waste Management Policy within every area of responsibility.

They will ensure that all staff under their direct control are aware of the details necessary to deal with the types of waste most frequently produced within their respective work area or activity and comply with these details. They must also be aware of what to do if other waste is encountered, even if that is some form of holding / emergency action.

They will ensure that the necessary local resources, financial and others are available to ensure that all aspects of the policy code of practice and WDDS can be met. If there are problems in this respect then this should be drawn to the attention of line management 6 until the problem is resolved. Notification in writing should be made to the Portering & Waste Manager of any problems or incidents relating to compliance.

They will ensure that: staff working within their areas of responsibility are appropriately trained, are provided with specialist equipment and protective clothing as necessary and receive appropriate inoculation as advised by Occupational Health, for example Hep B for waste porters.

Waste Porters have a duty to follow all safe systems of work in place to protect patients, staff, visitors and themselves from the risks created by handling, segregation, storage, transportation and collection of waste and reporting any non- conformance issues or bad practice to the Portering & Waste Manager.

Domestic Staff are responsible for ensuring an adequate supply of all disposal bags and unique identifiable clinical waste tags are provided at ward/department level. Domestic staff must ensure that all clinical waste bags are secured by using a unique identifying tag when being removed from the receptacle prior to transportation. Additionally under the direction of ward/department heads, all staff must ensure that waste awaiting collection is segregated.

Estates and Capital Projects Staff are responsible for the management and removal of building waste, fluorescent tubes, ash, oil and asbestos from the site and monitoring contractors to ensure their waste is removed from site in accordance with the Control of Contractors Policy (Estates).

Clinical, Nursing and Domestic Waste Staff all Clinical, Nursing and Domestic staff (including contracted and staff working under a contract with the Trust must follow all safe systems stated within this policy and associated procedures. They have a duty to segregate waste accurately, use the appropriate container, seal the bag/container in accordance with the procedure and place the waste in the agreed position for collection. All staff must ensure they attend relevant training provided with regards to waste.

All Employees within the Trust must adhere to this Policy and Procedures with regards to the safe handling, segregation, storage, collection and disposal of waste. All staff must ensure that they attend any relevant training provided with regards to waste, in particular accurate segregation

Estates and Capital Projects Staff are responsible for the management and removal of building waste, fluorescent tubes, ash, oil and asbestos from the site and monitoring contractors to ensure their waste is removed from site in accordance with the Control of Contractors Policy (Estates).

Contractors and External Agencies (cleaning/construction etc.) must ensure that contractors and their staff or any other external agencies employed on Trust premises are made aware and adhere to the contents of this Policy and associated procedures and where necessary, suitable training should be arranged prior to working on site.

For construction projects it is the responsibility of the employing manager/contact administrator to ensure the contractor and/or other external agencies employed by the Trust, have adequate and appropriate waste management policies and procedures and that all staff employed by the strictly adheres to them. During contract work, any waste produced where this forms part of the contract, the contractor is responsible for ensuring it is removed and disposed of in line with all relevant legislation and good practice.
Dangerous Good Safety Advisor (DGSA) will advise on Regulatory requirements for the packaging, marking, labelling, handling and training of staff involved in the movement of hazardous wastes.

The DGSA will also undertake examinations of practices and procedures of internal and external activities performed by Trust staff and those of contractors to ensure compliance standards are maintained.
The DGSA will produce the statutory annual Dangerous Goods report on Trust dangerous goods activities including, but not exclusively those related to wastes.
Healthcare waste breakdown
Our Healthcare waste is broken down into the following waste streams:
Clinical waste
Hazardous waste
General and recyclable waste
Clinical waste
This is defined in the Controlled Waste Regulations 1992 and refers to any waste that consists wholly or partly of the following:
Human or animal tissue
Blood or bodily fluids
Excretions
Drugs, chemicals and pharmaceutical products
Swabs or dressings
Syringes, needles, or other sharp instruments which, unless rendered safe, may prove hazardous to any person coming into contact with them
Clinical waste refers to any other waste arising from medical, nursing, dental, veterinary, pharmaceutical or similar practice, investigate, treatment, teaching or research.
Offensive waste

Offensive waste refers to waste generated by healthcare activities that is not infectious and does not contain pharmaceutical or chemical substances or sharps, but may cause offence to anyone who comes into contact with it.
Offensive waste is low risk to public health it doesn't need to be transported as dangerous goods.
Offensive waste refers to waste arising from items such as;
Nappies,
Hygiene wear
Any bodily fluid contaminated item with no risk of infection.
Infection clinical waste

This type of waste is determined by HP9–infectious which interprets as “substances containing viable micro-organisms or their toxins which are known or reliably believed to cause disease in humans or other organisms” and differentiates it from non-infectious (offensive) waste.
Infectious clinical waste is contained in two types of bags:
Orange Bags if the material has no chemicals or pharmaceuticals which is then disposed of by alternative treatment
Yellow Bags if the material has chemicals which is then disposed by incineration
Refer to Appendix 2 of this document, which summarises the waste categories & segregation procedures for handling clinical waste across MSE.
Hazardous waste
Waste is generally considered hazardous if it (or the material or substances it contains) is harmful to humans or the environment. Examples of hazardous waste include:
Acid and alkaline solutions
Paints, inks and resins
Solvents
Contaminated packing residues
Pharmaceutical compounds including cytotoxic and items hazardous to the
environment, flammable and corrosive
White goods
Batteries
Fluorescent lamps
TVs and PC screens or monitors
Refer to Appendix 2 of this document, which summarises the waste categories & segregation procedures for handling clinical waste across MSE
General and recyclable waste
This type of waste is defined under the provision of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 and can typically be divided in to the following categories:
General (domestic or household) waste contained in black bags or larger items such as broken furniture packing material
Waste for recycling in clear bags, e.g. card, rigid plastics, metals and paper, (specific) ink cartridges
Confidential paper waste disposed of in large lockable bins
WEEE (Waste, Electrical and Electronic Equipment), small electrical appliances, some of which may also be considered hazardous
Refer to Appendix 2 of this document, which summarises the waste categories & segregation procedures for handling clinical waste across MSE
11 Means of segregation
Appendix 2 outlines waste container/bags and colour types for the most frequently produced healthcare waste. These are in accordance with HTM07-01 Safe Management of Healthcare Waste
The colour coding of containers for waste is as follows.

Black Bags (at Broomfield & Southend only) contain used paper towels, flexible plastic packaging, food waste and un-recyclable waste items that are generally incinerated or sent to land-fill. Bags must not be overfilled and should have their necks secured as to render them leak proof, before being collected and transferred to the storage area. Full refers to 75% full or maximum 5kg in weight.
Clear Bags (at Broomfield & Southend only) contain card, paper, plastic drinks bottles and drink cans waste that is generally recycled.
Clear bags are used at Basildon both Domestic and General Recycling Waste.
Yellow Bags waste from Blood Sciences (Pathology) should go into yellow bags due to chemicals used.

Orange Plastic Lid Buckets (at Basildon only) can be used to safely transport glass to the Waste Compound. Glass should be clean and placed in the buckets which can be purchased via the Eros order system – code FSL413. The buckets are NOT designed for recyclable glass and are designed NOT to be opened after the lids are sealed in place. The buckets are therefore for single use only and their contents generally go to land-fill.
Confidential Waste is collected via the 360 litre locked waste bins.

Electrical and Electronic Items are governed by the Waste Electrical, Electronic and Equipment Directive (WEEE, Directive) and must be recovered, recycled or re-used and not disposed to landfill. Departments disposing of any WEEE items must inform the waste porters/manager of the ‘make, model and serial number' before sending to the Waste Compound. This is important as many items may be listed on the Trust Asset Register and will have to be de-listed.

Yellow Sharps Bins with Yellow Lids - All needles, syringes, cartridges, broken glass and other contaminated disposal sharp instruments, materials or items excluding cytotoxic and cytostatic materials (including waste pharmaceuticals). Controlled Drugs will be denatured before disposal in line with MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy

Yellow Sharps Bins with Purple Lids – All cytotoxic and cytostatic related needles, syringes, cartridges, broken glass and other contaminated disposal sharp instruments and materials (including waste pharmaceuticals)
Food Waste Caddies (only at Basildon) – all foods produced on wards
Under no circumstances must containers or bags be used for any other purpose than those listed above.
The segregation system will be rigorously audited and monitored to ensure compliance. No waste, which is identified for incineration must enter any other waste stream.
12 Sharps
Sharp devices are routinely used as part of healthcare practice, which poses a risk to staff, patient and public if not used and disposed of appropriately

It is the responsibility of all staff to safeguard the health of the general public, other members of staff and themselves. All staff should ensure that sharps are used and disposed of safely within the Trust and are aware of the action to take in the event of a needle stick or sharps injury and that these are managed in a timely, appropriate and consistent manner. The Safe Handling and Disposal of Sharps Policy sets out the approach of the Trust to the safe use and disposal of sharps and should be read in conjunction with the Trust's Waste Management Policy.
It is of crucial importance that sharps boxes are properly assembled before use and that lids cannot be removed from them either by accident or intention.

Safe handling and disposal of all sharps is the responsibility of the user in accordance with HTM 07-01 Safe Management of Healthcare Waste. Please refer to the Trust policies; Safe Handling and Disposal of Sharps and Management of Blood Borne Virus before using needles or other sharp instruments.
Sharps will be stored in containers, which comply with British Standard 7320:1990. This standard specifies the following:
Prior to any localised changes in the storage containers for sharps, the Waste Manager must be consulted
Containers must be puncture resistant and leak proof
Capable of being handled and moved with the minimal danger of the contents spilling or falling out;
Provided with handles that are not part of any closure device. The position of the handle should not interfere with the normal use of the container

Provided with an aperture which in normal use will inhibit removal of the contents, but will ensure that it is possible to place items intended for disposal, into the sharps container, using one hand without contaminating the outside of the container
Have a closure device attached for sealing when three quarters full for disposal
Have a clearly marked line to indicate when the container is three quarters full
Made of materials, which care be incinerated
Yellow, purple or orange in colour as appropriate
Clearly marked with the words: DANGER! CONTAMINATED SHARPS ONLY DESTROY BY INCINERATION
Provided with an area for clearly marking the user / originating department name

Syringes (with or without medicinal content), needles, cartridges, broken contaminated glass and other sharp items: this waste must be placed in rigid plastic sharps bins, sealed before transport or transfer to the Waste Compound. The handling of these containers is the same as that of the orange and yellow bags.
It is a legal requirement for us to make sure that NO sharp items are placed in orange, yellow or black bags or in a waste cart which contains any of these bags.
13 Healthcare waste sacks
The Waste Manager will ensure that only sacks, which confirm to the following specifications, are issues within the Trust:
Comply with UN specifications
Meet the performance specifications set out by the NHS supplies
The bag must be suitable for the finally disposed method
Be compatible with container or fittings in use
Be of the appropriate colour as stipulated in HTM 07-01
14 Operational processes

Waste Disposal Data Sheets (WDDS) A standard data sheet is compiled, for each category of waste, giving specific details relevant to the particular category of waste will be held locally within the department. These include information on applicable hazards, appropriate storage agreements, colour codes, spillage arrangements etc. It is intended that each Data sheet will include all necessary information relating to that particular category or type of waste.

COSHH Requirements the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 require that Risk Assessments be carried out for all processes and activities. In addition, the COSHH Regulations 2002 require specific assessments to be carried out for tasks involving hazardous substances. Therefore managers are responsible for ensuring that COSHH risk assessments are carried out for all waste generating or waste handling tasks in accordance with the Trust's COSHH Policy.

Segregation all waste generated within the Trust must be disposed of in accordance with the appropriate Waste Disposal Data Sheet, unless alternative routes have been agreed with the Portering & Waste Manager.
Container Identification Clinical waste bags and containers generated within the Trust when ¾ full or finished with, must be swan necked and tagged, using the
unique identifiable tag supplied by Domestic staff. All sharps containers should have the label completed when assembled and closed for disposal in order to identify the origin.

Colour Coding All waste categories will be allocated the internationally recognised colour code as set out in the Health Technical Memorandum 07:01 Safe Management of Healthcare Waste. Further details can be found in Appendix 2

Spillage of Biological Fluids The spillage of biological fluids presents an infection risk to those who come into contact with them. Therefore any spillage of body fluids must be dealt with immediately.
If possible do not leave the area where the spillage occurred until it has been correctly contained and hazard cones employed to warn others of the spillage.
Refer to the Cleaning Policy for managing biological fluid cleaning
Disinfectant The Trust uses DIFF X for Surfaces for the effective disinfecting of hard surfaces in a concentration of one sachet to 5 litres of cold water.
Large Spillage of Bodily Fluids (e.g. blood and urine) – see Appendix 3

Cytotoxic Spillages All wards/departments involved with the handling of cytotoxic agents have cytotoxic spill kits available to them on their stock list. Spill kits can be ordered from the site Pharmacy on request or can be directly ordered by the clinical area as appropriate. A cytotoxic spillage kit must be available on all wards and in all clinics where chemotherapy is given. Any spillage should be dealt with immediately by the staff member who has administered the drug. Mopping up must never be delegated to domestic staff.

Radioactive Waste Spillages wear protective disposable gloves and aprons. Always contain the area of spillage. Minor spills e.g. splashed urine on skin, should be removed by washing under running water. Contaminated gloves and aprons can be placed in normal clinical waste bags. Larger Spills of Radioactive Urine etc. should be soaked up with Paper towel. Repeat the process after wetting the same area at least twice. The contaminated material must then be double bagged and kept for a minimum of 24hrs in a low traffic area of the ward or department before disposal. NOTE. Never mop the floor as the mop head will then become radioactive. Nuclear Medicine staff are available for advice.
15 Personal protective equipment (PPE)

Waste Porters - to protect the hands, legs and feet against needle stick injuries, staff responsible for the removal and transport of waste must ensure that they are wearing, needle stick injury gloves, (rubber or surgical gloves will not protect hands against sharps or needle stick injury).

All staff - when handling and disposing of clinical waste, staff should ensure they wear disposable gloves and aprons and appropriate hand decontamination when the gloves are removed. Removed gloves and aprons should then be disposed of via clinical waste.

Relevant PPE is provided via line management and must be worn in accordance with the policy. Any issues relating to the lack of PPE must be escalated to staffs line manager immediately and tasks not undertaken without their use.
16 Waste produced by microbiology department

Due to the nature of the work performed within the Microbiology Department waste that contains high numbers of micro-organisms is routinely generated. It is recognised that the Microbiology Department has a duty of care to ensure that this type of waste does not enter the general waste disposal streams in an untreated format. To address this issue all waste generated within Microbiology that has the potential to harbour micro-organisms is treated in one of the following ways:

All waste generated within the Laboratory that has been contaminated with micro- organisms is autoclaved within the Microbiology Department. Subsequent to autoclaving the waste is treated as clinical waste.
This includes:
all specimens that are no longer required for the analytical processes utilised in Microbiology
all disposable items used to propagate and examine live cultures of micro- organisms
all disposable items used within the Virology Department
All waste generated within the Laboratory that has not been directly contaminated with micro-organisms is treated as clinical waste and is not autoclaved within the Microbiology Department.

All waste, without exception, generated within the higher risk Laboratory is autoclaved within Microbiology. Subsequent to autoclaving the waste is treated as clinical waste and is entered into the Trust Waste Disposal System.

Any large items of waste, such as obsolete equipment, that have been routinely used within either the Laboratory are cleaned with appropriate disinfectant before leaving the Microbiology Department and entering the relevant Trust Waste Disposal Route.”
Community waste (midwives)

Particular attention should be paid to the carriage of small quantities of waste in vehicles, as happens in community nursing for example midwifery. If a bag of infectious clinical waste is placed directly into any vehicle, including a car, the vehicle and driver must comply with the Carriage of Dangerous Goods and Use of Transportable Pressure Equipment regulations. Community nurses are not to transport waste sacks alone but use rigid containers as set out below which can be transported securely in a vehicle and returned to the Trust for appropriate disposal.

Clinical Waste: Orange sacks must be placed inside a rigid container before transporting them, with the container acting as a temporary bin. When the home visit is complete, the orange sack should be securely fastened with a tag, the label completed and then securely closed before transporting. The boxes must be secured in the vehicle in an upright position when transporting. Waste must then be disposed of in the clinical waste wheelie bin at the hospital site.

Sharps Waste: All sharps containers when used in the community must be correctly assembled, label completed and securely closed prior to transportation. Sharps containers must be transported securely in an upright position in the vehicle. Sharps containers must be used for single use only and must NEVER be transported without being securely closed.
Sharps containers used in the community by Trust staff must be compliant with colour coding as detailed with the waste management and sharps policies and disposed of at the hospital site accordingly.

Anatomical: Placentas are deemed as anatomical waste and therefore must be transported in red colour coded rigid containers. Placentae must be placed into a clinical waste bag, swan-necked and securely zip-tied before placing into the rigid container. Rigid containers must be securely closed and transported upright securely in the vehicle. NB: These containers are NOT leak-proof.
Human tissue transfer notes must be completed for all anatomical waste and porters contacted to collect on return to site for appropriate disposal.
Redundant equipment

From time-to-time pieces of equipment become redundant or reach the end of their expected working life. These should all be disposed of in accordance with Standing Financial Instructions and decontaminated in accordance with the Decontamination Policy.
The following types of equipment must be condemned as follows:
Medical Equipment: Redundant items of medical equipment must be returned to the Bio-Medical Engineering department (BME/ MEMS) for condemnation and disposal.
Any electrical items must be disposed of in accordance with Waste Electrical & Electronic Equipment (WEEE) regulations.
Furniture: Porters will collect furniture which can then be either stored for re-use or condemned for disposal.
Mattresses: Mattresses must be condemned in accordance with the Mattress Policy and disposed of as clinical waste.
Electrical Equipment (Non-IT): Porters will collect for recycling in accordance with Waste Electrical & Electronic Equipment (WEEE) regulations.
IT Equipment: all IT equipment must be returned to IM&T department for repair or condemnation and disposed of in accordance with Waste Electrical & Electronic Equipment (WEEE) regulations.
The following types of equipment must be condemned as follows:

Medical Equipment: Redundant items of medical equipment must be returned to the Bio-Medical Engineering department (BME) for condemnation and disposal. Any electrical items must be disposed of in accordance with Waste Electrical & Electronic Equipment (WEEE) regulations.
Furniture: Porters will collect furniture which can then be either stored for re-use or condemned for disposal.
Mattresses: Mattresses must be condemned in accordance with the Mattress Policy and disposed of as clinical waste.
Electrical Equipment (Non-IT): Porters will collect for recycling in accordance with Waste Electrical & Electronic Equipment (WEEE) regulations.
IT Equipment: all IT equipment must be returned to IM&T department for repair or condemnation and disposed of in accordance with Waste Electrical & Electronic Equipment (WEEE) regulations.
19 Disposal of liquid via drainage system
Discharge to Service Water Only rainwater is disposed of via this route. Under no circumstances must any other substances be disposed of via the surface water system.
Discharges to Sewer (other than domestic sewerage) are made in accordance with the environmental requirements
Discharges of certain substances into the sewer prohibited, these are:
Petroleum spirit and other volatile or flammable organic solvents.
Calcium Carbide
Sludge's arising from the pre-treatment of the trade effluent before discharge to the public sewer.
Waste liable to form viscous or solid coatings or deposits on any part of the sewerage system through which the trade effluent is to pass.
Substances of a nature likely to give rise to fumes or odours injurious to persons working in the sewers through which the trade effluent is to pass.
Halogenated hydrocarbons.
Halogen substitutes phenolic compounds
Thiourea and its derivatives.
Cooling of Condensing water.
Radionuclides except those agreed under EA Authorisation into designated drains

Disposal of some prohibited substances may be made via the Laboratory Chemical Store (see WWDS No 5.0). Others may require special arrangements under The Control of Pollution (Hazardous waste Regulations 2005.
20 Emergency procedures
If the arrangement outlined on the Waste Disposal Data Sheets are followed then the need for emergency procedures will be reduced.
Never touch waste without gloves on, particularly spilt waste where the source is unidentifiable.
Spillage arrangements are contained in the WDDS. If there is any doubt then the Risk Manager should be contacted, and the immediate area isolated until advice has been received.

A Trust Accident / Incident form (DATIX form) must be completed and submitted for any  accident  /  incident involving  waste.  It  may  also  be  necessary  to  consider implementing the Trust Serious Untoward Incident Policy.

Any member of staff who sustains a laceration, cut, stab or needle stick injury whilst dealing with any waste category should immediately attend the Accident and Emergency Department or Occupational Health.

Any on-road incident involving infectious or hazardous goods, wastes or materials must also be reported to the DGSA who may in some circumstances be required by law to complete an independent inquiry for upward reporting to the Competent Authority.
Storage

Full waste bags and rigid plastic containers shall be placed in the waste holds and/or the Waste Compound storage yellow carts and not allowed to accumulate on floors, corridors, wards or unsuitable areas. Under no circumstances must clinical and non-clinical waste be mixed or come into contact with each other during transportation or storage.

Yellow carts will be cleaned and disinfected by the incumbent clinical waste provider and located so as not to obstruct access routes or form potential fire hazards in lobbies. They shall be secured to prevent access at all times.

Clinical waste holds must be clean and tidy and kept secure and locked at all times with access limited to authorised personnel only. The areas should be assessed as to risk regularly by each ward to ensure compliance with the following storage regulations and practices.
Clinical bags must not be mixed with other coloured bags in the same cart
A separate yellow cart must be used for each colour of clinical bag
Sharps containers must not be placed in any cart within the waste hold.

The location of satellite storage areas (serving individual wards and departments) in which to store the collection bins in a safe manner will be agreed by the Portering & Waste Manager and Ward/Department Manager.
Healthcare waste bins stored in the satellite storage units must be kept in a locked room/cupboard and/or bins should be kept locked at all times.
Ward/Department Managers must ensure that only authorised, trained personnel should be able to gain access to healthcare waste.
Healthcare waste that has been collected from across the Trust will be stored in the appropriate bulk waste prior to transportation.
The bulk waste bay will be clearly marked for healthcare waste only Healthcare waste must be stored separately from domestic general waste.
Personal hygiene facilities will be made available for staff involved in the transportation and storage of healthcare waste.
22 Transportation of waste

A registered waste carrier must undertake all transportation of wastes off site and all movements of waste must be accompanied by the correct documentation. All queries regarding the movement and transportation of waste should be raised through the Portering & Waste Manager who has the overall responsibility of these contracts. All waste carriers must also comply with the requirements of The Carriage of Dangerous Goods and Use of Transportable Pressure Equipment Regulations 2009 as amended 2011 and ADR, for the correct provision of equipment and suitable driver training.

All matters pertaining to waste transfer should be made to the Site Waste Manager who is responsible for the movement of waste around the Trust sites, however the Trust has an appointed Dangerous Goods Safety Advisor (DGSA) to ensure compliance and advice on matters relating to The Carriage of Dangerous Goods and Use of Transportable Pressure Equipment Regulations 2009 as amended 2011

A Hazardous Waste Consignment note must be completed for every movement of hazardous waste off site and copies of these must be kept by all parties for a period of 3 years and held by the Portering & Waste Manager so they can be made available for inspection by the Environment Agency if required. All other waste transported off site must have a Waste Transfer Note and be kept by all parties for a period of 2 years.

Radioactive waste may only be transported off site by a named contractor specified by the Environment Agency Authorisation issued under RSA93, to the incineration sites listed under the said Authorisation. Copies of the Authorisation are held in the Nuclear Medicine and Biochemistry Departments. The contractor must be furnished with signage and documentation in accordance with CDG & ADR.
Disposal

Clinical waste disposal will be only carried out by a licensed waste provider with the correct Consignment Note completed to record all relevant information, identification and European Waste Catalogue code. The document must be signed off by a member of staff.
Washing facilities for waste porters or staff must be available, suitable protective clothing and equipment supplied and maintained
Emergency spillage procedures must be developed by managers and made available during times when waste collection services are in operation.
24 Final disposal
Final disposal of waste will take place from a recognised centre unless specifically otherwise agreed with the Portering & Waste Manager, this will normally be from the designated Waste Compounds.
25 Minimisation of waste

Sustainable development and carbon management are corporate responsibilities. We are committed to ensure sustainable development in all our activities. This ambition is embedded in the Trust's core vision that supports the values of excellence and innovation to deliver exceptional healthcare services.

The Portering & Waste Manager and the Head of Sustainable Development and Strategic Projects will work together to embed the principles of the Sustainable Development Management Plan by undertaking such initiatives as are necessary and practicable to reduce waste generation.

Segregation of waste at the point of production into suitable colour-coded packaging is vital to good waste management practices. This policy sets out sustainable options for waste reduction and recycling initiatives to reduce the environmental impact from the amount of waste that the Trust produces.
Designs of new buildings and all major refurbishment work will include improving systems for waste minimisation and providing effective, compliant standards of waste management.
26 Financial arrangements

The cost of normal waste disposal requirements are funded centrally, although it is recognised that some departments / areas will, from time to time generate an unusual quantity, or type of waste that will fall outside this normal funding. In these circumstances the Portering & Waste Manager should be consulted.
When requesting approval for funding for items over £5000, a disposal charge must be built into the cost for any replacement items.
Training requirements

It will be the duty of Ward and Department Managers at all levels to ensure that their staff are training in the appropriate methods of disposal of waste produced in their area and that their staff are fully aware of the proper way to handle, segregate and dispose of waste. Any training/retraining given to staff must be recorded on personal staff records accordingly.
Portering and Domestic staff are required to complete specific waste management training in regards to their day to day responsibilities and procedures in handling waste
All employees that are required to handle and remove healthcare waste must be properly trained in safe handling and disposal procedures.
Appropriate PPE must be provided to relevant personnel and training given on its use.
Training must be updated as and when policy and procedures change and at least annually.
All new employees / transferring employees must be given training within their localised area as part of their local induction.
